thread.title: Ohio Senate GOP leaders favor Rep. Stephanie Kunze over Rep. Cheryl Grossman for open seat
thread.title_full: Ohio Senate GOP leaders favor Rep. Stephanie Kunze over Rep. Cheryl Grossman for open seat | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: Ohio Senate GOP leaders favor Rep. Stephanie Kunze over Rep. Cheryl Grossman for open seat
text:
Senate GOP leaders have apparently picked sides between a pair of state House members who are preparing to battle over an open Franklin County Senate seat.
Rep. Cheryl Grossman, a four-term Republican from Grove City, announced last week that she intends to run for the 16th District held by Sen. Jim Hughes, R-Columbus, who is term-limited.
But as she was announcing her run, the Senate GOP Caucus, headed by Senate President Keith Faber, R-Celina, was getting out the word on Capitol Square that it is backing two-term Rep. Stephanie Kunze, R-Hilliard, for the seat.
Although the caucus has not made a formal endorsement, sources said the message went out from Faber and others, including Christina Lisotto, the Senate GOP’s chief fundraiser.
Sources speculated that the early caucus backing, which comes well before the county Republican Party has officially weighed in, is designed to keep Grossman from building up a larger fundraising advantage. Grossman had about $150,000 in her campaign account at the end of June, while Kunze had about $38,000.
“I’ve let it be known that we may endorse Stephanie Kunze,” Faber said. “I thought it was important that I let Cheryl Grossman know that we would make a decision sometime in the near future.”
The district covers much of western Franklin County, including Worthington and Grove City. Republican Mitt Romney beat President Barack Obama in the district by nearly 2 percentage points in 2012.
Grossman said she was not told why the Senate GOP Caucus is backing Kunze, whom she called a “ very nice person.”
“Based on prior elections, I didn’t think that would happen,” Grossman said of the stance of the caucus.
Grossman highlighted some of her endorsements from local officials.
“I’m telling you there are a tremendous number of businesspeople and community leaders that are extremely supportive,” she said.
Faber said the caucus is looking for the candidate who would best represent the district and has the best chance to win what could be a strongly contested general-election race. No Democratic candidate has joined the race yet.
>> Keep up on political news and insights with our Dispatch Politics newsletter. Sign up today. 
“Stephanie has a long track record of being able to work with people across the spectrum and has a long track record of being an effective legislator,” Faber said.
Kunze declined to comment.
By running for the Senate, Kunze opens her House seat, giving Hughes the chance to switch chambers again and extend a legislative career that began in 2000.
“At this point, I’m seriously looking at it, but I have not made a final decision,” Hughes said.
Hughes declined to comment on whether he will endorse anyone in the Senate primary, although Faber said he thinks Hughes is supporting Kunze.
Grossman has held elected office for 20 years, including 12 as mayor of Grove City and the past seven in the Ohio House.
“I’m very proud of my record on behalf of the people I represent,” she said, highlighting her legislative efforts to eliminate Ohio’s estate tax and reform municipal income-tax laws. “It needs to be the decision of the voters, and I’ll stand on my record any day.”
Regarding an official caucus endorsement, Faber said: “At this point, we’re just trying to make sure we have all the data.”
Rep. Mike Duffey, R-Worthington, said he considered running for the Senate but instead will run for re-election.
Senate Republicans have a few other open-seat primary fights on their hands next year.
In the 24th Senate District in suburban Cleveland, Rep. Mike Dovilla, R-Berea, recently became the third candidate in a GOP primary that also includes Rep. Nan Baker, R-Westlake, and former state Rep. Matt Dolan, son of Cleveland Indians owner Larry Dolan.
Sen. Tom Patton, R-Strongsville, who is term-limited from the 24th District, is expected to run for Dovilla’s House seat and has endorsed him in the Senate race.
A pair of former House members, John Adams and Matt Huffman, will square off in the 12th District in western Ohio to replace Faber, who is term-limited at the end of 2016.
jsiegel@dispatch.com 
@phrontpage
